subtopics.subtopic_title: Special Populations
subtopics.concept: Special populations, particularly children under five years of age, face a significant burden of malnutrition globally and in India, with distinct epidemiological patterns. Globally, as of 2022, approximately 149 million children under five were stunted, 45 million were wasted, and 37 million were overweight, highlighting the double burden of malnutrition. Stunting prevalence has stagnated in recent years, while wasting affects 6.7% of children under five worldwide, with South Asia bearing a disproportionate burden. Over one-third of the world’s stunted children (around 56 million) reside in South Asia, which also has the highest wasting rates. Acute malnutrition affected 45 million children globally in 2022, with approximately 12 million suffering from severe wasting (SAM). Undernutrition remains a leading underlying cause of child mortality, contributing to approximately 45% of all under-five deaths globally. India exemplifies the global malnutrition crisis, carrying one of the highest burdens of child undernutrition. According to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS-5, 2019–21), 35.5% of Indian children under five are stunted, 19.3% are wasted, and 32.1% are underweight, reflecting slight improvements from NFHS-4 (2015–16). However, severe wasting prevalence increased marginally from 7.5% in 2015–16 to 7.7% in 2019–21. India accounts for approximately 40% of the world’s stunted children, with over 60 million affected. Malnutrition rates vary widely across the country, with historically disadvantaged states like Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, and Madhya Pradesh showing the highest prevalence. District-level disparities are stark, with stunting exceeding 50% in at least 17 districts (e.g., areas of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Meghalaya), while wasting rates surpass 30–40% in certain pockets, such as Karimganj in Assam. Socioeconomic disparities further exacerbate the issue, with tribal, rural, and poorer populations disproportionately affected. Despite numerous national programs, malnutrition remains a major contributor to child mortality, with a 2019 Lancet study attributing 68% of under-five deaths in India to malnutrition-related factors, equivalent to an estimated 700,000 deaths in 2017. The long-term developmental and economic impacts are profound, including poor academic performance and a 2–3% loss in adult GDP due to reduced human productivity.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Follow-Up and Counselling
subtopics.concept: Follow-up and counselling are essential components in the management of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) and moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) in children, aimed at consolidating recovery and preventing relapse. After discharge from inpatient care or during outpatient management, a structured follow-up protocol is implemented to monitor progress and address potential concerns. In the early follow-up phase, spanning weeks 1 to 4 post-discharge, children are typically reviewed weekly or biweekly. During each visit, growth parameters such as weight, mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), and occasionally height are measured. For example, in community programs, health workers or Anganwadi centres may weigh the child weekly. Weight gain is a critical indicator of recovery, with a good weight gain defined as at least 5–10 g/kg/day. If weight gain is static or declining, healthcare providers investigate potential causes, including feeding adherence, ongoing illnesses, or socioeconomic challenges, such as the family’s inability to afford diverse foods or running out of ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF). Anthropometric targets are established for recovery. For SAM, the goal is to achieve a weight-for-height z-score (WHZ) ≥ –2 or MUAC ≥ 125 mm on two consecutive visits, at which point the child is considered "recovered." For MAM, the target is WHZ ≥ –2 or an equivalent MUAC value. These targets are assessed at every follow-up visit. Clinical monitoring during follow-up includes a brief examination for signs of relapse or complications, such as the return of edema, new skin lesions, thrush, or respiratory issues. Appetite and activity levels are also evaluated, as improved appetite and playfulness are positive indicators of recovery, whereas anorexia or lethargy may signal the need for readmission. Developmental progress is monitored over time, and stimulation therapy is reinforced with caregivers when necessary. Early identification of concerns and timely interventions during follow-up are crucial to ensuring sustained recovery and preventing malnutrition-related morbidity.

case_studies.title: Follow-Up of Undernutrition in a 2-Year-Old in Rural India
case_studies.vignette: A 2-year-old boy from a rural village in India presents for his third follow-up visit after being discharged from inpatient care for severe acute malnutrition (SAM). His mother reports that he has been eating the recommended homemade foods, but his appetite has decreased over the past week. She also mentions that he has been less active and irritable. On examination, the child appears mildly lethargic with no visible edema or skin lesions. His weight has remained static compared to the previous visit, and his mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is 117 mm, showing no improvement. His temperature is 98.4°F, and his respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute. The mother shares concerns about financial difficulties in purchasing diverse foods and limited access to the Anganwadi center that provides nutritional support.
case_studies.learning_objective: Identify barriers to recovery and counsel caregivers on nutrition and follow-up adherence in undernourished children.
